In March 1945, the 1st Tank Division with its 5th Armored Regiment was reassigned to the Japanese home islands in preparation for the expected invasion by Allied forces.

2nd Tank Division ('Sensha Dai-ni Shidan', nicknamed 'Geki', meaning 'Attack') was raised in Manchukuo on June 24, 1942 and stationed in Mudanjiang, under command of Lieutenant General Tasuku Okada.
Like 1st Tank Division, its initial mission was border patrol of Manchukuo's frontier with the Soviet Union but its forces were sent to various locations: 11th Tank Regiment was sent to the Kuriles and assigned to 91st Division, recon unit and anti-aicraft guns were directed to China. Remaining units of the 2nd Tank Division were reassigned to the Japanese 14th Area Army, and sent to the Philippines in August 1944. They were almost destroyed in the Battle of Luzon. The 2nd Tank Division was reconstituted in Japan as a training unit after the disaster in the Philippines.
Formation of 3rd Tank Division.

Japanese 3rd Tank Division ('Sensha Dai-san Shidan', nicknamed 'Taki', meaning 'Torrent'), was raised in Inner Mongolia in 1942 as part of the Japanese Northern China Area Army. Its 2 first commanders were Lieutenant General Isaku Nishihara (until January 1944) and Lieutenant General Hideo Yamaji.\n3rd Tank Division participated in Operation Ichi-Go in Northern China (1944) and thereafter, its tank regiments were assigned to many different locations: 8th Armored Regiment was sent in Rabaul, 12th Armored Regiment was withdrawn to bolster the defenses of Seoul, 13th Armored Regiment was withdrawn to Tianjin in 1944, and ended the war in Changsha. 17th Armored Regiment ended the war in Tianjin.
Formation of 4th Tank Division.

Japanese 4th Tank Division ('Sensha Dai-yon Shidan', nicknamed 'Hagane', meaning 'Steel') was the 4th and last armored division raised by Japan during the war. It was set up on July 6, 1944 in Chiba, near Tokyo. Division was assigned to 36th Army Corps, and placed under command of Lieutenant General Shiori Nagura.\nSimilar to the German Panzer-Lehr-Division, it was created out of the training departments of the Armor School, Cavalry School, Field Artillery School and Military Engineering School of the Imperial Japanese Army Academy, its remaining students and staff. 4th Tank Division was equipped with the finest and most advanced armaments, including a significant number of Type 3 Chi-Nu medium tanks and Type 3 Ho-Ni III tank destroyers. Nevertheless, the division lacked both infantry and self-propelled gun regiments.
Formation of SNLF brigades in 1937.

Following the escalation of hostilities in Shanghai in August 1937, the Navy organized additional SNLF battalions, which were often raised for a specific task and then disbanded.\nIn addition to the Shanghai SNLF, three other SNLF from this period remained active throughout the war. These were the Sasebo 8th SNLF, Yokosuka 4th SNLF and Maizuru 1st SNLF. These three SNLF were large but relatively lightly armed, and they remained on Hainan on garrison duty throughout the war.
Formation of Independent Mixed Brigades for garrison duties in China.

In February 1938, Imperial Japanese Army decide to raise brigades for garrison duties in China: 1st and 2nd Independant Mixed Brigades (Dokuritsu Konsei Ryodan) were reformed alongside 1st, 2nd, 3rd and 5th Infantry Mixed Brigade ('Hohei Konsei Ryodan'). These brigades were later used to form division-sized units.
Formation of Border Garrisons in Manchukuo.

On March 1939, Border garrisons ('Kokkyo Shubitai') units were formed in Manchukuo to protect the border with Soviet Union. These units were a mix of infantry, artillery and cavalry battalions for recon purpose. 5 more were ordered next year.
Formation of Karafuto Independent Mixed Brigade.

Karafuto Independent Mixed Brigade was formed in Toyohara, southern part of Sakhalin Island, on September 1939, upon regiments of the 7th Division. In February 1945, this brigade formed the nucleus of the 88th Infantry Division.
New Brigades for garrison duties in China.
In november 1939, Japan raised another 10 IMB for garrison duties in China. You will receive 11th and 18th Independent Mixed Brigades but you'll have to build the other brigades by yourself.
New Border Garrisons units for Manchukuo.
5 new garrisons divisions were raised in Manchukuo in March 1940 and were attached to 4th, 5th and 20th Armies.
Form the South Seas Detachment.

South Seas Detachment ('Nankai Shitai') was a brigade-size force of the Imperial Japanese Army designed in 1941 to seize Wake, Guam and the Gilberts. As part of the South Seas Force, it fell under command of the Imperial Japanese Navy. It later rejoined the 55th Division for the New Guinea Campaign.
Send support brigades for Kwantung army.
From July 11th to August 8th, no less than 17 artillery regiments, 17 anti-aircraft regiments, 5 anti-tank battalions and 2 tank regiments were sent in Manchuria.
Tauran Incident.

The Tauran Incident was a border clash between Soviet Union and Japan and their respective puppet states of Mongolia and Manchukuo that happened in March 1936.\nA force of 100 Mongol soldiers with 6 Soviet advisors took control of the contested village of Tauran on March, 11th. Imperial Japan Army mounted a successful counterattack, supported by light tanks, armored cars and warplanes, that overwelmed Mongol defenders who were forced to retreat leaving 59 killed...
Manchurian Cavalry.

Manchukuo Imperial Army, armed force of the Japanese State of Manchukuo made a large use of cavalry brigades to secure its territory, for border duties and local unrests repression.
Typical Manchurian cavalry brigade was composed of a headquarters, three cavalry regiments, and an artillery company, for a total of 1,500 men and 1,500 horses.

§RHere you can receive a whole Manchukuo Cavalry Corps as an expeditionnary force...§B
Tensions with China.

In 1937, Imperial General Staff started to move troops to reinforce North China army for an upcoming confrontation with China.
20th Infantry Division was called from Korea, 2nd Independant Mixed Brigade from Kwantung Army, 5th, 6th, 10th Infantry Division from Japanese Mainland. This was also including 1st Tank Regiment (Colonel Baba) and 2nd Tank Regiment (Colonel Imada) from Kurume and Chiba.

§RNote for player: You'll have to ship troops manually to Manchuria.§B
Kanchazu Island Incident.

The Kanchazu Island Incident took place in late June 1937 between Japanese and Soviet forces on the Amur river. Soviet forces from the Amur Flotilla started to unload troops on the Kanchazu Island located in the center of the river, crossing the official frontier between Manchukuo and Soviet Union. Japan reacted quickly and mounted a counterattack with its 1st Infantry Division.  49th Infantry regiment led by Colonel Mihara Kanae inflicted substancial losses, including destruction of a Type 1124 BKA gunboat – by combination of machinegun and 37 mm At guns fire. Soviet forces were forced to withdraw and on June 29th, japanese ambassador Shigemistu Mamoru met foreign Minister Maxim Litvinov who accepted that the island would remain to Manchukuo. Apparently, the Soviets were more concerned with events unfolding in North China and Europe, as well as internal strife.
Yellow river flood.

The 1938 Yellow River Flood was a flood created by Nationalist Government in Central China in an attempt to slow down Japanese advance in China. Dykes on the Yellow river were opened near Huayuankou on early June 1938 and floods covered and destroyed thousands of square kilometers of farmland. Casualties were heavy with 400,000 to 500,000 dead and 3 million refugees. Strategic value of the flood has been questionned as it didn’t stop Japanese advance towards Wuhan. It also produce a long term psychological effect on the Chinese population:  large parts of people blamed the KMT for being responsible of the losses and turned themselves to Japanese or Communist Chinese...\n\n§RNote for player: due to the flooding, the infrastructure in the area southeast of Zhengzhou will be heavily damaged and much harder to attack due to the mud and destruction for 4 months, the coal mines present there will also be operating at greatly reduced rate.§B
Yellow river flood.
Yellow river flood.
Yellow river flood.
Japan starts to reinforce Kwantung Army after Barbarossa.

On July 1941, war between Germany and Soviet Union pushed Japanese High Command to start reinforcing Kwantung Army. A weakened Soviet Union could be an interesting target.\nJapanese forces in the area were enlarge from 400.000 to 700.000 men with new units - 3rd Cavalry Division, 51st and 57th Infantry Divisions – and new tank and artillery brigades to strengthen already existing units.
Protect our country from air raids.

After Doolittle air raid in April 1942, Japan started being concerned about allied bombings raids. Japanese mainland AA units were equipped with around 150 anti-aircraft guns, most of which were obsolete, and its personnel were poorly trained. In November 1942, a significant effort was decided to reach a total of 20 Air regiments.\n\n§RIt's up to you to decide if you need some more anti-aicraft units.§B
Japanese "Cleanup trio".

Tainan Naval Air Group ('Tainan Kaigun Kokutai') was an elite fighter unit of the Imperial Japanese Navy that spawned more aces than any other Japanese unit during WW2. It was deployed in March 1942 in Rabaul (New Britain) and Lae (New Guinea) as a part of IJN 11th Air Fleet. Tainan Naval Air Group fought New Guinea and Guadalcanal campaigns, destroying many allied aircrafts. This unit was well known by allied forces who rapidly identify three Japanese Aces as the 'Cleanup Trio':\n\nHiroyoshi Nishizawa, aka 'Demon of Rabaul', Toshio Ota and Saburo Sakai.
Yamamoto's inspection.

In April 1943, Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, commander of the Imperial Japanese Navy, scheduled an inspection tour of the Solomon Islands and New Guinea. He planned to inspect Japanese air units participating in Operation I-Go that had begun on April 7. In addition, the tour would boost Japanese morale following the disastrous Guadalcanal Campaign and its subsequent evacuation during January and February. Staff officers made several warnings about risks taken by the IJN commander in chief...
Yamamoto's inspection.

In April 1943, Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, commander of the Imperial Japanese Navy, scheduled an inspection tour of the Solomon Islands and New Guinea. He planned to inspect Japanese air units participating in Operation I-Go that had begun on April 7. In addition, the tour would boost Japanese morale following the disastrous Guadalcanal Campaign and its subsequent evacuation during January and February.\nUS intelligence and Navy cryptographers deciphered Japanese communications and discovered that Yamamoto will personally fly to Bougainville. American high command took this opportunity to get rid of admiral Yamamoto and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz ordered an interception that would be called 'Operation Vengeance'.
Yamamoto's flight to Balalae.

Admiral Yamamoto decided to begin his tour flying with his staff in 2 medium bombers covered by 6 navy fighters from Rabaul to Balalae Airfield, on a island near Bougainville in the Solomon Islands. Depart was schedule on April 18, 1943 at 6:00, ignoring warnings of officiers thinking that this kind of frontline flight was too risky.\nYamamoto also ignored that US military intelligence had intercepted and decrypted japanese communications in the area...
Yamamoto has been shot!.

10 minutes before landing at Balalae, Admiral Yamamoto’s flight was ambushed by american P-38s. Its aircraft – a G4M 'Betty' - was shot down and crashed in the jungle, 14 km from the town of Panguna. Vice-admiral Matome Ugaki escape death by crash-landing in the water. A total of 19 japanese pilos and superior officers were killed during the ambush.
Japanese opinion was told about Yamamoto’s death nearly one month later and its ashes return to Japan at Kisarazu aboard battleship Musashi on May 23rd, 1943.

The 'Navy ko incident' - japanese name for Yamamoto’s killing –  delivered a severe blow to Japanes forces moral and organization and a certain boost to USA’s ones...
Yamamoto has been shot!.

Led by Captain Thomas G. Lanphier Jr, a 18 P-38s flight took of on April 18, 1943 from Kukum Field on Guadalcanal island and made an indirect approach to avoid Japanese detection. At 9:34, american fighter met Yamamoto’s flight and shot down its G4M 'Betty'. Part of Yamomoto’s staff that was on the second bomber – including vice admiral Matome Ugaki – escape death by crash-landing in the water.
A Controversy began later about who shot down the admiral’s aircraft as both Captain Lanphier et Lieutnant Rex T. Barber claimed the kill...

Operation Vengeance delivered a severe blow to Japanes forces moral and organization.
Formation of PETA.

PETA – 'Pembela Tanah Air' or 'Defenders of the Homeland' - was an Indonesian volunteers militia raised by Japan in late 1943 to protect occupied Indonesia from possible allied landings. Up to 69 battalions were raised, mostly in Java (37,000 men) and Sumatra (20,000 men). This force was disbanded on August 17, 1945 by Japanese order..
The Shanghai Incident.

The Shanghai Incident, also called January 28 incident, was a conflict between Empire of Japan and Republic of China in the Shanghai International Settlement that happened in 1932.\nJapanese aggressivness in China provoked anti-japanese demonstrations in Shanghai, including the beating and killing of a buddist monk. Japanese navy and army forces overreacted and the conflict degenerated into heavy fight, involving more than 100.000 men, 80 ships and 300 planes facing the 50.000 chinese soldiers of 5th Army and 19th Route Army.\nOn May 5, China and Japan signed the Shanghai Ceasefire Agreement that made Shanghai a demilitarized zone and forbade China to garrison troops while allowing the presence of a few Japanese units in the city. China was allowed to keep only a small police force within the city.
Imperial Guard.

The Imperial Guard of the Imperial Japanese Army was formed in 1867. Organized and trained along French Military lines, Imperial Guard rapidly totalize 12.000 men separated in 2 brigades of 2 regiments. It was based in Tokyo and recruited nationally. After the Russo-Japanese War in 1905, a second Guard Brigade was formed from indigenous Formosans.\nIn 1920 the Guards Cavalry Regiment, Guards Field Artillery Regiment, Guards Engineer Battalion, Guards Transport Battalion, plus other Guards service units were added.
Imperial Guard Expansion (1939).

From 1937 to 1939 the Guards Engineer Battalion was expanded into a regiment as was the Guards Transport Battalion. In September 1939, the Division staying in Tokyo was split into the 1st and 2nd Guards Brigades, while the Formosa Mixed Brigade was sent as reinforcements to the IJA 11th Army in Central China. It was later used to form the 48th Infantry Division.\nThe 1st Guards Brigade, which contained the 1st and 2nd Guards Infantry Regiments, the cavalry regiment, and half of the support units, was transferred to South China. Here it became known as the Mixed Guards Brigade. In October 1940, it joined other Japanese units occupying French Indochina.\nThe 2nd Guards Brigade, which contained 3rd and 4th Guards Regiments, also went to China. In 1940, it went to Shanghai before being posted to Hainan Island. In June 1941, the 5th Guards Infantry Regiment joined the 2nd Guards Brigade becoming the Imperial Guard Division.
Imperial Guard Expansion (1943).

In May 1943, all designated Imperial Guard units were renamed again.\nThe Mixed Guards Brigade in Tokyo became the 1st Guards Division ('Konoe Dai-ichi Shidan') which now consisted of the 1st, 2nd, 6th Guards Regiments, with the 1st Guards Cavalry Regiment, 1st Guards Field Artillery Regiment, 1st Guards Engineer Regiment and 1st Guards Transport Regiment, and other support units. Based in Tokyo, it remained in Japan mainland until the end of war.\nThe Imperial Guard Division became the 2nd Guards Division ('Konoe Dai-ni Shidan'). Its composition wasn't different from the former Imperial Guard Division.
Imperial Guard Expansion (1944).
The 3rd Guards Division ('Konoe Dai-san Shidan'), which never left Japan, was formed in 1944. It consisted of the 8th, 9th and 10th Guards Regiments and stayed in Japan to defend the homeland.
Formation of 109th Division.

109th Division ('Dai-hyakukyu Shidan', nicknamed 'Tan Heidan', meaning Courage Division) was reformed in May 1944 from 1st Independent Mixed Brigade and other Bonin Islands garrisons reinforced by recruits from Kofu mobilization district. 109th Division was made as a Type-A Division (Reinforced) because it had two infantry brigades (5000 men each) with two infantry regiments each. It was assigned to the 31st Army, garrisoned on the volcanic islands of Iwo Jima and Chichi Jima. 109th Division, under command of Lieutenant-General Tadamichi Kuribayashi was wiped out by American forces from February to March 1945 in Battle of Iwo Jima.\n\n§RNote for player: Although 109th Division was separated in 2 brigades, you will receive it as a full unit in Kanazawa§B.
Formation of IJN 11th Air Fleet.

Japanese 11th Air Fleet ('Dai-Juichi Koku Kantai') was a grouping of naval aviation and surface units from the Imperial Japanese Navy. It was consisting of land-based bombers, fighters, flying boats and seaplane tenders. 11th Air Fleet was created on January 15, 1941, placed under command of Combined Fleet and Southern Area Fleet after December 1942.
Japanese engineering vehicule 'SS-Ki'.

The Soko Sagyo Ki ('armoured work vehicule'), also known as the SS-Ki, was a fulltrack engineering vehicle introduced in 1931 and designed to destroy Soviet fortified positions along the Manchurian border. In fact, it became a multirole armored vehicule: trench digging, mine clearing, barbed wire cutting, mass decontamination, chemical weapons employment, use as a crane vehicle, a bridgelayer or as a flamethrower tank.
The first four SS-Ki were assigned to the 1st Mixed Tank Brigade sent to China. During the Battle of Beiping–Tianjin in 1937, the vehicles were used as flamethrower tanks. SS-Ki were sent to japanese engineer brigades and armored divisions, notably in the 2nd Tank Division transferred to the Philippines in late 1941.
